author: @mrbismarck
text: The first meeting of (almost) every major data project I complete features some variation of "these numbers are wrong."  We always have to loop back through a data correction/data cleanse process and it's important to build in time for this.  Learning how to identify engaged users and then get them to spend time testing can also be a key skill.

author: @seefore5409
text: SQL + Excel. Truly master those and everything else is gravy. Get data > Scrub Data > Make it usable for the layman > Tell them what it means and be prepared to repeat. I hit Senior DA this year with about 8 years experience and these two skills, more than anything else got me there. 100k salary in a small city.

author: @vikingshark2634
text: Crime Analyst here. Scrubbing data, prep etc is *at least* 70% where I am. Cops aren't data entry specialists and everything that's supposed to go into their respective fields goes into the narrative supplement, and the fields I've asked to make mandatory, IT has been sitting on for two years so far. I'm making visualizations, products and analyses based on data I can't enter, verify, edit or quality control. "Data" in my job means reading through stories written by people who aren't writers and who don't care about analysis.
